idioms.sense: to work, study, etc. too hard or for too long
examples: He's been overdoing things recently.

idioms.sense: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: You didn't get caught last time, but don't push your luck!

idioms.sense: to take a risk because you have successfully avoided problems in the past
examples: Don't push things—we don't want it all to go wrong now.

idioms.sense: actually what somebody claims that something is
examples: Are you sure it's the real thing (= love), not just infatuation?

idioms.sense: the way things seem to be organized; the way somebody wants everything to be organized
examples: My personal problems are not really important in the overall scheme of things.

I don't think marriage figures in his scheme of things.

idioms.text: the shape of things to come
idioms.sense: the way things are likely to develop in the future
examples: Are solar-powered cars the shape of things to come?
This new system could be the shape of things to come.

idioms.sense: used to say ‘yes’ to a suggestion or request
examples: ‘Are you coming?’ ‘Sure thing.’

idioms.sense: to relax and avoid working too hard or doing too much
examples: The doctor told me to take it easy for a few weeks.
I like to take things easy when I’m on holiday.

idioms.text: take it/things one day at a time
idioms.sense: to not think about what will happen in the future
examples: I don't know if he'll get better. We're just taking it one day at a time.

idioms.text: take things/it one day at a time
idioms.sense: to not think about what will happen in the future
examples: I don't know if he'll get better. We're just taking things one day at a time.

idioms.text: there’s only one thing for it
idioms.sense: there is only one possible course of action

idioms.text: these things are sent to try us
idioms.sense: used to say that you should accept an unpleasant situation or event because you cannot change it
a situation or an activity of the type mentioned
examples: She really didn't want to be involved in the whole family thing.

idioms.sense: used to introduce an important fact, reason or explanation
examples: I'm sorry my assignment isn't finished. The thing is, I've had a lot of other work this week.

idioms.sense: used to introduce a problem about something/somebody
examples: The thing with Karl is, he's always late.

idioms.text: things that go bump in the night
idioms.sense: used to refer to ghosts and other supernatural things that cannot be explained
examples: There are mysterious lights in the sky and things that go bump in the night.

idioms.sense: to do what people or society expect, especially in a difficult situation
examples: He did the decent thing and resigned.

idioms.text: too much of a good thing
idioms.sense: used to say that, although something is pleasant, you do not want to have too much of it
because you have been busy with various problems, events or things you had to do
examples: I completely forgot her birthday, what with one thing and another.

idioms.sense: to arrange something in a particular way, especially by being clever
examples: Can you work it so that we get free tickets?

idioms.sense: to arrange something in a particular way, especially by being clever
examples: Can you work things so that we get Friday afternoon off?

senses.text: used for referring to a person or thing that is not near the speaker or as near to the speaker as another

examples: The world exists in time and space.

idioms.sense: used to say that something should have happened before now
if you do something against time, you do it as fast as you can because you do not have much time
examples: They're working against time to try and get people out of the rubble alive.

idioms.sense: earlier/later than was expected
examples: We finished 15 minutes ahead of time.
The plane took off an hour behind time.

idioms.sense: having advanced or new ideas that other people use or copy later

idioms.text: all the time | the whole time
idioms.sense: during the whole of a particular period of timevery often; repeatedly
examples: The letter was in my pocket all the time (= while I was looking for it).
She leaves the lights on all the time.

idioms.sense: always
examples: Our representatives are ready to help you at all times.
Hot water is available at all times.

idioms.sense: even when the circumstances are very good
examples: He's never very happy at the best of times—he'll be much worse now!

idioms.sense: at one time; togetherused to introduce a fact that is different and must be considered
examples: She was laughing and crying at the same time.
You have to be firm, but at the same time you should try and be sympathetic.

idioms.sense: separately or in groups of two, three, etc. on each occasion
examples: We had to go and see the principal one at a time.
She ran up the stairs two at a time.
He surfs the internet for hours at a time.

idioms.text: at my, your, his, etc. time of life
idioms.sense: at the age you are (especially when you are not young)
examples: Eyesight doesn't get any better at my time of life.

idioms.sense: sometimes
examples: He can be really bad-tempered at times.
The rain will become heavy at times in the afternoon.
He can be rather moody at times.

idioms.sense: to mark or follow the rhythm of music, by waving a stick, tapping your foot (= hitting it against the floor), etc.
examples: She beat time with her fingers.

idioms.text: before my, your, his, etc. time
idioms.sense: happening before you were born or can remember or before you lived, worked, etc. somewherebefore the usual time in somebody’s life when something happens
examples: ‘Were you taught by Professor Pascal?’ ‘No, he was before my time.’
She got old before her time.

idioms.sense: old-fashioned in your ideas, methods, etc.

idioms.text: be in the right place at the right time
idioms.sense: to be able to take advantage of opportunities when they come
examples: His success was down to being in the right place at the right time.

idioms.sense: to still be alive after the time when you were expected to dieto be doing something that other people are likely to soon stop you from doing
examples: He’s been living on borrowed time ever since his last heart attack.
According to the latest opinion polls, the government is living on borrowed time.

idioms.sense: used to encourage somebody who has not been successful at something
examples: Never mind— better luck next time.
If you didn't win a prize, better luck next time.

idioms.sense: to wait for the right time to do something
examples: He decided to bide his time until he got an opportunity to talk to her alone.

idioms.sense: to do something in order to delay an event, a decision, etc.
examples: The negotiators kept the gunman talking to buy time for the hostages.

idioms.sense: to say or decide that it is time for something to finish
a very difficult or unpleasant job or time
examples: I've had a devil of a job finding you.

idioms.sense: to spend time in prison
whenever there is a choice
examples: I don't really like cities—give me the countryside every time.

idioms.sense: if you do something for old times’ sake, you do it because it is connected with something good that happened to you in the past
for a short period of time but not permanently
examples: You can leave your suitcase here for the time being.

idioms.sense: beginning on that day; from that time
examples: From that time forth she gave me endless friendship and encouragement.

idioms.sense: occasionally but not regularly
examples: She has to work at weekends from time to time.

idioms.sense: to delay something so that you can have more time to make a decision, deal with a problem, etc.
to deliberately make a situation difficult and unpleasant for somebody
examples: They really gave me a hard time at the interview.

idioms.sense: used to say that you prefer a particular thing or person to the one that has just been mentioned
examples: We don't go out much. Give me a quiet night in front of the TV any day!

idioms.sense: to have no difficulties or problems
examples: He’s had an easy time of it since he married Lucy.

idioms.sense: to enjoy yourself very much

idioms.text: have a lot of time for somebody/something
idioms.sense: to like and be interested in somebody/something
examples: I've always had a lot of time for Mary.

idioms.text: have no time for somebody/something | not have much time for somebody/something
idioms.sense: to dislike somebody/something
examples: I have no time for lazy people like Steve.

idioms.sense: to have many problems or difficulties to deal with; to not be successful
examples: He’s had a thin time of it since losing his job.

idioms.text: have the time of your life
idioms.sense: to enjoy yourself very much

idioms.text: have time on your hands | have time to kill
idioms.sense: to have nothing to do or not be busy

idioms.text: have a whale of a time
idioms.sense: to enjoy yourself very much; to have a very good time
examples: The kids had a whale of a time at the theme park.

idioms.sense: when enough time has passed
examples: It is possible that in the course of time a cure for cancer will be found.
In the course of time, I began to understand.

idioms.sense: when the time is appropriate, usually after a long period
examples: I have no doubt that she’ll tell us in the fullness of time.

idioms.sense: early; with enough time so that you are not in a hurry
examples: Get to the airport in good time.

idioms.sense: used to say that something will be done or will happen at the appropriate time and not before
examples: Be patient, Emily! All in good time.

idioms.sense: at the very last moment; just before something bad happens, so that you manage to avoid it, but only just
examples: They escaped from the smoke-filled house just in the nick of time.

idioms.sense: so soon or so quickly that it is surprising
examples: The kids will be leaving home in no time.

idioms.text: in olden times (also in the olden days)
idioms.sense: a long time ago in the past
examples: In olden times people would gather in town squares to gossip and exchange stories.

idioms.sense: how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people
examples: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.
She just ignores all the criticism and continues on her own sweet way.

idioms.sense: when you are ready and not sooner
examples: Don't hassle him! He'll do it in his own good time.

idioms.sense: in your free time and not when you usually work or study
after a period of time when a situation has changed
examples: They learned to accept their stepmother in time.
You'll get used to the work in time.

idioms.sense: not late; with enough time to be able to do something
examples: Will we be in time for the six o'clock train?
The ambulance got there just in time (= to save somebody's life).

idioms.sense: used to say that you think somebody should do something soon
examples: It's about time you cleaned your room!

idioms.text: it’s just/only a matter of time (before…)
idioms.sense: used to say that something will definitely happen, although you are not sure when
examples: It's only a matter of time before they bring out their own version of the software.

idioms.sense: to change and develop your ideas, way of working, etc. so that you do what is modern and what is expected
examples: Many complained that the Royal Family had failed to move with the times.

idioms.text: kill time | kill an hour, a couple of hours, etc.
idioms.sense: to spend time doing something that is not important while you are waiting for something else to happen
examples: We killed time playing cards.

idioms.sense: used to say hello to somebody you have not seen for a long time
to complete a journey quickly
examples: We made excellent time and arrived in Spain in two days.

idioms.sense: to do something quickly or very often because you wish you had started doing it sooner
examples: I’ll have to work hard now to make up for lost time.

idioms.text: many a time | many’s the time (that)…
idioms.sense: many times; frequently
to pass the time while you wait for something more interestingto make marching movements without moving forwards
examples: I'm just marking time in this job—I'm hoping to get into journalism.

idioms.text: (the) next, first, second, etc. time round
idioms.sense: on the next, first, etc. occasion that the same thing happens
examples: He repeated none of the errors he'd made first time round.
This time round it was not so easy.

idioms.text: nine times out of ten | ninety-nine times out of a hundred
idioms.sense: used to say that something is usually true or almost always happens
examples: Nine times out of ten she gives the right answer.

idioms.text: ninety-nine times out of a hundred
idioms.sense: almost always
used to say that something should have happened before now

idioms.text: not give somebody the time of day
idioms.sense: to refuse to speak to somebody because you do not like or respect them
examples: Since the success of her novel, people shake her hand who once wouldn't have given her the time of day.

idioms.text: (there is) no time like the present
idioms.sense: now is the best time to do something, not in the future
that has ever existed
examples: Many rated him the best singer of all time.

idioms.sense: used, especially at the beginning of stories, to mean ‘a long time ago in the past’
examples: Once upon a time there was a beautiful princess.

idioms.sense: at the arranged or correct time; not late
examples: The train arrived right on time.

idioms.text: pass the time of day (with somebody)
idioms.sense: to say hello to somebody and have a short conversation with them
to find or create reasons why something has to be delayed, often so you have longer to prepare for it
examples: His legal team, clearly playing for time, sought to have the case heard a month later.

idioms.sense: a situation in which you have to do something or finish something very fast before it is too late
examples: Getting food to the starving refugees is now a race against time.

idioms.sense: something that you feel shows what things are like now, especially how bad they are
examples: The increasing number of people owning guns is an alarming sign of the times.

idioms.sense: it is better to deal with something immediately because if you wait it may become worse or more difficult and cause extra work

idioms.text: take it/things one day at a time
idioms.sense: to not think about what will happen in the future
examples: I don't know if he'll get better. We're just taking it one day at a time.

idioms.text: take your time (over something) | take your time to do something/doing something
idioms.sense: to use as much time as you need without hurryingused to say you think somebody is late or is too slow in doing something
examples: There's no rush—take your time.
You certainly took your time getting here!

idioms.sense: to spend some time away from your usual work or activity in order to rest or do something else instead
examples: She is taking time out from her music career for a year.
We stopped for a well-earned rest.
Let’s take a break.
The drug brought a brief respite from the pain.
Take time out to relax by the pool.
This delay gives the party a breathing space in which to sort out its policies.

idioms.text: there’s a first time for everything
idioms.sense: the fact that something has not happened before does not mean that it will never happen

idioms.text: third time lucky (US English third time is the charm)
idioms.sense: used when you have failed to do something twice and hope that you will succeed the third time

idioms.text: time after time | time and (time) again
idioms.sense: often; on many or all occasions
examples: You will get a perfect result time after time if you follow these instructions.
Time and again, the girls have shown how strong and determined they can be.

idioms.sense: one and a half times the usual rate of pay
examples: We get time and a half on Sundays.

idioms.sense: time seems to pass very quickly
examples: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

idioms.sense: time is valuable, and should not be wasted
used to say that somebody can wait for something to happen or can wait before doing something
used to say that something used to happen in the past
examples: Time was when you could go for a walk in the country and not see another person for miles.
Time was when we never needed to lock our house at night.

idioms.text: time (alone) will tell | only time will tell
idioms.sense: used to say that you will have to wait for some time to find out the result of a situation
examples: Only time will tell if the treatment has been successful.

idioms.text: the whole time | all the time
idioms.sense: during the whole of a particular period of timevery often; repeatedly
examples: My keys were in my pocket the whole time (= while I was looking for them).
He drums his fingers on the table the whole time—it's very annoying.

idioms.text: somebody can take it or leave it
idioms.sense: used to say that you do not care if somebody accepts or rejects your offerused to say that somebody does not have a strong opinion about something
examples: Dancing? I can take it or leave it.

idioms.sense: to have the qualities, ability, etc. needed to be successful

idioms.text: I, you, etc. can’t take somebody anywhere
idioms.sense: used to say that you cannot trust somebody to behave well in public
examples: You haven’t spilled your coffee again! I can’t take you anywhere!

idioms.text: take something as it comes | take somebody as they come
idioms.sense: to accept something/somebody without wishing it/them to be different or without thinking about it/them very much in advance
examples: She takes life as it comes.

idioms.sense: to suppose; to assume
examples: I take it you won't be coming to the party?

idioms.sense: used to emphasize that what you are going to say is the truth
examples: Take it from me—he'll be a millionaire before he's 30.

idioms.text: take it/a lot out of somebody
idioms.sense: to make somebody physically or mentally tired
examples: Looking after small children really takes it out of you.

idioms.text: take it on/upon yourself to do something
idioms.sense: to decide to do something without asking permission or advice
to need a lot of effort or time; to be very difficult to do
used as an exclamation when you are hitting somebody or attacking them in some other way

result.note: For the special uses of to in phrasal verbs, look at the entries for the verbs. For example see to something is in the phrasal verb section at see.
